targets.expr: sum(last_over_time(mssql_info{alias=~"$alias", info="cores_per_socket"}[24h])) by (job, alias, instance, edition, productlevel, productversion, virtual_machine_type)
sum(last_over_time(mssql_parameters{alias=~"$alias", state="value", name="max server memory (MB)"}[24h])) by (job, alias, instance)
sum(last_over_time(mssql_parameters{alias=~"$alias", state="value", name="min server memory (MB)"}[24h])) by (job, alias, instance)
sum(last_over_time(mssql_parameters{alias=~"$alias", state="value", name="min memory per query (KB)"}[24h])) by (job, alias, instance)
sum(last_over_time(mssql_parameters{alias=~"$alias", state="value", name="max worker threads"}[24h])) by (job, alias, instance)
sum(last_over_time(mssql_parameters{alias=~"$alias", state="value", name="max degree of parallelism"}[24h])) by (job, alias, instance)

panels.description: The CPU bandwidth usage by all requests in all workload groups belonging to this pool.

targets.expr:
sum(avg(avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="CPU usage %"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)) by (alias, db)) by (alias)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: DB CPU (%)

panels.description: = (total_physical_mem. - available_physical_mem.) / total_physical_mem.
panels.title: OS Memory Usage (%)

panels.description: Indicates the number of requests per second that had to wait for a free page.
panels.title: Free list stalls/sec

panels.description:
- Indicates the minimum number of seconds a page stays in the buffer pool on this node without references.
- If this value is small, system performance may deteriorate, so the cause must be analyzed and action taken. Larger values ​​indicate better performance and stability.
panels.title: Page Life Expectancy (s)

panels.description: Wait Time in Seconds
panels.title: Wait Time (s)

panels.description: Number of Transact-SQL command batches received per second. This statistic is affected by all constraints (such as I/O, number of users, cache size, complexity of requests, and so on). High batch requests mean good throughput.
panels.title: Batch Requests/sec

panels.description: Indicates the number of requests per second to find a page in the buffer pool
panels.title: Page lookups/sec

panels.description: Indicates the number of physical database page reads that are issued per second. This statistic displays the total number of physical page reads across all databases.
panels.title: Page reads/sec

panels.description: Counts the number of users currently connected to SQL Server.
panels.title: User Connections

panels.description: The number of currently active transactions of all types.
panels.title: Active Transactions

panels.description: Number of times locks on a table were escalated to the TABLE or HoBT granularity.
panels.title: Table Lock Escalations/sec

panels.description: Number of unrestricted full scans per second. These can be either base-table or full-index scan
panels.title: Full Scan/sec

panels.description: Number of qualified range scans through indexes per second.
panels.title: Range Scan/sec

panels.description: Number of index searches per second. These are used to start a range scan, reposition a range scan, revalidate a scan point, fetch a single index record, and search down the index to locate where to insert a new row.
panels.title: Index Searches/sec

panels.description:
information about processes that are running on an instance of SQL Server.
(sys.sysprocesses)
panels.title: Processes

panels.description: Number of currently blocked processes.
panels.title: Processes blocked

panels.description: Number of currently blocked processes.
panels.title: Processes blocked

panels.description: Top SQL ordered by Elapsed Time
The CPU bandwidth usage by all requests in all workload groups belonging to this pool.

targets.expr:
sum(avg(avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="CPU usage %"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)) by (alias, db)) by (alias)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: DB CPU (%)

panels.description: CPU & Memory Size
= (total_physical_mem. - available_physical_mem.) / total_physical_mem.
panels.title: OS Memory Usage (%)

panels.description: Size of physical memory available, in GB.
panels.title: OS Memory Free (GB)

panels.description: Displays the percentage of total OS memory utilized by SQL Server. This metric helps monitor memory allocation efficiency and assess if SQL Server's memory usage aligns with the system's overall capacity.
panels.title: mssql memory % of OS

panels.description: Specifies the percentage of committed memory that is in the working set
panels.title: mssql memory util (%)

panels.description: Total time, in milliseconds, that the users waited for reads issued on the file.
panels.title: read_io_stall (ms)

panels.description: Total time, in milliseconds, that users waited for writes to be completed on the file.
panels.title: write_io_stall (ms)

panels.description: The number of page faults that were incurred by the SQL Server process
panels.title: mssql page fault

panels.description: SQL Server resident memory size (AKA working set).
panels.title: mssql resident memory

panels.description: SQL Server committed virtual memory size
panels.title: mssql virtual memory

panels.description: Tablespace Usage %
panels.title: Disk Usage (%)

panels.description: Available free space on the volume.
panels.title: Disk Free (GB)

panels.description: DB file Used GB
panels.title: DB file Used GB

panels.description: Number of Transact-SQL command batches received per second. This statistic is affected by all constraints (such as I/O, number of users, cache size, complexity of requests, and so on). High batch requests mean good throughput.
panels.title: Batch Requests/sec

panels.description:
information about processes that are running on an instance of SQL Server.
(sys.sysprocesses)
panels.title: Connections (processes)

panels.description: Number of temporary tables/table variables in use.
panels.title: Active Temp Tables

panels.description: Number of temporary tables/table variables created per second.
panels.title: Temp Tables Creation Rate

panels.description: Active parallel threads
panels.title: Active parallel threads

panels.description: Number of currently blocked processes.
panels.title: Processes blocked

panels.description: Number of pages flushed to enforce the recovery interval settings.
panels.title: Background writer pages/sec

panels.description: Total number of log bytes flushed.
panels.title: Log Bytes Flushed/sec

panels.description: Total number of logins started per second. This does not include pooled connections.
panels.title: Logins/sec

panels.description: Counts the number of users currently connected to SQL Server.
panels.title: User Connections

panels.description: Number of SQL cursor requests received by server.
panels.title: Cursor Requests/sec

panels.description: Number of severe errors that caused SQL Server to kill the connection.
panels.title: Kill Connection Errors /sec

panels.description: Number of user errors.
panels.title: User Errors /sec

panels.description: Number of Network IO waits started per second of the selected type of wait.

targets.expr: avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias",gauge="Network IO waits", db="Waits started per second"}[$intv])

avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias",gauge="Network IO waits", db="Waits started per second"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: NW waits - Waits started / sec

panels.description: Average time for the Network IO waits.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias",gauge="Network IO waits", db="Average wait time (ms)"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: NW waits - Avg wait time (ms)

panels.description: Number of processes currently waiting.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias",gauge="Network IO waits", db="Waits in progress"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: NW waits - Waits in progress

panels.description: Active Session List
Number of unrestricted full scans per second. These can be either base-table or full-index scan
panels.title: Full Scan/sec

panels.description: Number of qualified range scans through indexes per second.
panels.title: Range Scan/sec

panels.description: Number of index searches per second. These are used to start a range scan, reposition a range scan, revalidate a scan point, fetch a single index record, and search down the index to locate where to insert a new row.
panels.title: Index Searches/sec

panels.description: Number of records per second fetched through forwarded record pointers.
panels.title: Forwarded Records/sec

panels.description: Number of page splits per second that occur as the result of overflowing index pages.
panels.title: Page Splits/sec

panels.description: Number of times locks on a table were escalated to the TABLE or HoBT granularity.
panels.title: Table Lock Escalations/sec

panels.description: Number of work files created per second. For example, work files could be used to store temporary results for hash joins and hash aggregates.
panels.title: Workfiles Created/sec

panels.description: Number of work tables created per second. For example, work tables could be used to store temporary results for query spool, lob variables, XML variables, and cursors.
panels.title: Worktables Created/sec

panels.description: Number of pages allocated per second from mixed extents. These could be used for storing the IAM pages and the first eight pages that are allocated to an allocation unit.
panels.title: Mixed page allocations/sec

panels.description: Number of extents allocated per second in all databases in this instance of SQL Server.
panels.title: Extents Allocated/sec

panels.description: Indicates the number of requests per second that had to wait for a free page.
panels.title: Free list stalls/sec

panels.description: Indicates the number of requests per second to find a page in the buffer pool
panels.title: Page lookups/sec

panels.description: Indicates the number of physical database page reads that are issued per second. This statistic displays the total number of physical page reads across all databases.
panels.title: Page reads/sec

panels.description: Indicates the number of physical database page writes that are issued per second.
panels.title: Page writes/sec

panels.description: Indicates the number of buffers written per second by the buffer manager's lazy writer. The lazy writer is a system process that flushes out batches of dirty, aged buffers (buffers that contain changes that must be written back to disk before the buffer can be reused for a different page) and makes them available to user processes. The lazy writer eliminates the need to perform frequent checkpoints in order to create available buffers.
panels.title: Lazy writes/sec

panels.description: Total number of non-free cache pages in the buffer pool extension file.
panels.title: Extents Allocated/sec

panels.description: Indicates the number of pages read per second in anticipation of use.
panels.title: Readahead pages/sec

panels.description: Indicates the number of pages flushed to disk per second by a checkpoint or other operation that require all dirty pages to be flushed.
panels.title: Checkpoint pages/sec

panels.description: all memory clerks that are currently active in the instance of SQL Server.
panels.title: All Memory Clerks

panels.description: This memory clerk keeps track of commonly the largest memory consumer inside SQL Server - data and index pages. Buffer Pool or data cache keeps data and index pages loaded in memory to provide fast access to data.
panels.title: Memory - SQLBUFFERPOOL

panels.description: This cache store is used for caching ad hoc queries, prepared statements, and server-side cursors in plan cache. Ad hoc queries are commonly language-event T-SQL statements submitted to the server without explicit parameterization.
panels.title: Memory - CACHESTORE_SQLCP

panels.description: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/system-dynamic-management-views/sys-dm-os-memory-clerks-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver16
panels.title: Memory - ALL MEMORYCLERK_

panels.description: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/system-dynamic-management-views/sys-dm-os-memory-clerks-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver16
panels.title: Memory - ALL CACHESTORE_

panels.description: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/system-dynamic-management-views/sys-dm-os-memory-clerks-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver16
panels.title: Memory - ALL USERSTORE_

panels.description: Indicates the percentage of pages found in the buffer cache without having to read from disk. The ratio is the total number of cache hits divided by the total number of cache lookups over the last few thousand page accesses.
panels.title: Buffer Cache Hit (%)

panels.description: SQL Server uses memory to store objects such as stored procedures, ad hoc and prepared Transact-SQL statements, and triggers.

targets.expr: avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="Cache Hit Ratio", object="MSSQL$SQLSVC:Plan Cache", db="_Total" }[$intv])

avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="Cache Hit Ratio", object="MSSQL$SQLSVC:Plan Cache", db="_Total" }[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Plan Cache Hit (%) - Total

panels.description: - SQL Plans : Query plans produced from an ad hoc Transact-SQL query, including auto-parameterized queries, or from Transact-SQL statements prepared using sp_prepare or sp_cursorprepare.

targets.expr: avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="Cache Hit Ratio", object="MSSQL$SQLSVC:Plan Cache", db="SQL Plans"}[$intv])

avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="Cache Hit Ratio", object="MSSQL$SQLSVC:Plan Cache", db="SQL Plans"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Plan Cache Hit (%) - SQL Plans

panels.description: - Object Plans : Query plans generated by creating a stored procedure, function, or trigger.

targets.expr: avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="Cache Hit Ratio", object="MSSQL$SQLSVC:Plan Cache", db="Object Plans"}[$intv])

avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="Cache Hit Ratio", object="MSSQL$SQLSVC:Plan Cache", db="Object Plans"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Plan Cache Hit (%) - Object Plans

panels.description: Catalog metadata cache hits and lookups.

targets.expr: avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="Cache Hit Ratio", object="MSSQL$SQLSVC:Catalog Metadata", db="_Total"}[$intv])

avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="Cache Hit Ratio", object="MSSQL$SQLSVC:Catalog Metadata", db="_Total"}[$intv]offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Catalog Cache Hit (%) - Total

panels.description: Catalog metadata cache hits and lookups.

targets.expr:
avg_over_time(mssql_perf_gauge{alias=~"$alias", gauge="Cache Hit Ratio", object="MSSQL$SQLSVC:Catalog Metadata", db!~"master|model|msdb|mssqlsystemresource|tempdb|_Total"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv)
>= ((1-$use_diff)*100000000000000000000000000000000000000000)

panels.title: Catalog Cache Hit (%) - DBs

panels.description: - https://fiftynine.io/sql/wait-type-reference/

targets.expr:
topk(10, sum(
label_replace(
  rate(mssql_wait_time_seconds{alias=~"$alias", wait_category!="CPU"}[$intv]),
  "short_wait_type",
  "$1",
  "wait_type",
  "^(.{1,18}).*|^(.*)$"
)
) by (alias, wait_category, wait_type, short_wait_type)) * 1000 > 0.1

panels.title: Wait Type Time (ms)

panels.description: - https://fiftynine.io/sql/wait-type-reference/

targets.expr:
topk(10, sum(
label_replace(
  rate(mssql_wait_time_seconds{alias=~"$alias", wait_category!="CPU"}[$intv] offset $diff_intv),
  "short_wait_type",
  "$1",
  "wait_type",
  "^(.{1,18}).*|^(.*)$"
)
) by (alias, wait_category, wait_type, short_wait_type)) * 1000 > 0.1

panels.title: Wait Type Time ( Diff : $diff_intv )

panels.description: - https://fiftynine.io/sql/wait-type-reference/

targets.expr:
topk(10, sum(
label_replace(
  rate(mssql_wait_time_seconds{alias=~"$alias", wait_category=~".*Latch.*|.*Lock.*"}[$intv]),
  "short_wait_type",
  "$1",
  "wait_type",
  "^(.{1,18}).*|^(.*)$"
)
) by (alias, wait_category, wait_type, short_wait_type)) * 1000

panels.title: Lock & Latch Wait Type Time (ms)

panels.description: Number of Deadlocks/sec For Total Databases Of SYS.DM_OS_PERFORMANCE_COUNTERS. (Delta value)
panels.title: Dead Locks/Sec

panels.description: Number of lock requests per second that timed out, including requests for NOWAIT locks.
panels.title: Lock Timeout/Sec

panels.description: Number of lock requests per second that timed out, including requests for NOWAIT locks.
panels.title: Lock Wait Time (ms)

panels.description: Number of lock requests per second that timed out, including requests for NOWAIT locks.
panels.title: Latch Wait Time (ms)

list.label: Group
list.name: group

list.label: interval

previous days, You can input directly.
ex) 4d, 6w
